resources.string: Need some information or help getting started using the app? Read the guide.
What is the current cloud coverage?
Are you sure you want to stop the survey? All data will be lost!
Start the survey once ready in order to start collecting data.
What is the current wind speed?
Share any remarks about your survey
Thank you for your contribution towards cleaner oceans. Make sure you remember to upload your results!
Survey is done! Continue to finalize.
There are currently no profiles, create a profile using the 'new profile' button.
Are you sure you want to delete this profile?
Failed to find profile, please restart the app and try again.
As a ‘debris spotter’ on a moving vessel, you are looking for debris that is floating at sea, and recording what you see in The Ocean Cleanup app.

Each survey takes 30 minutes and requires your full attention and sufficient battery of your device. Choose the side of the vessel- starboard or port side - that allows you to best see floating debris, given the available sunlight and wind conditions.

Your standing point must remain the same during the entire 30-minutes visual survey.

If this is your first visual survey using this app, make sure to take some time to have a look at our guide and settings. The settings tab gives you the option to choose between Metric and Imperial systems for the measurements you will have to guess during the survey.

Navigate to the ‘Welcome’ page of The Ocean Cleanup app and press ‘Start a new survey’.

The app will then give you the opportunity to either select your existing profile or create a new one. Provide your name, boat name, and platform height, which is a guess of the distance between your eyes and the mean water line.

Next, it will ask you the current wind speed (use an anemometer, or guess it) and cloud coverage (guess it).

You are now ready to get the 30 minutes ocean watch started.

You are now in a screen with a countdown timer that tells you how much time you have left before the 30 minutes survey is over.

You should focus your attention on looking for debris floating within a 90-degree arc encompassing the area ahead of the ship and one side of the track-line.

Your should be searching for debris in closeby waters - 0 - 10 meters from the boat’s track-line - but debris sighted at any distance can be recorded.

When you spot a debris, press ‘New Sighting’. You will then have to log the debris amount, material, type, size, and distance from the vessel track-line.

When the 30 minutes ocean watch is over, your phone will vibrate to let you know that the survey is over.\n\nYou wil then have the opportunity to write down any remarks you may have, such as app improvement suggestions and reports of unusual sightings (e.g. marine life, abrupt weather condition changes).
Before you start a new survey, it is important that you have filled in your personal and vessel details. This enables us to link the survey-data to the right vessel and team
How to setup your observer profile
To setup your observer profile, go to the profiles page using the menu or simply press 'start survey'. On the profiles page you will be able to create a new profile using the 'new profile' button.

Is the answer to your question not available in this guide? Do you experience a problem with the use of the app or when conducting a survey? Please don't hesitate to contact us.\n\napp@theoceancleanup.com
"When I orbited the Earth in a spaceship, I saw for the first time how beautiful our planet is. Mankind, let us preserve and increase this beauty and not destroy it."
YURI A. GAGARIN, first man in space.

Plastic pollution has become a major hazard to marine life and is also leading to aesthetic degradation, economic losses, and impacts on human health. The Ocean Cleanup aims to mitigate ocean plastic pollution by starting effective at-sea cleanup operations. By developing technologies to extract, prevent, and intercept plastic pollution. The Ocean Cleanup’s goal is to fuel the world’s fight against oceanic plastic pollution, by initiating the largest cleanup in history.\n\nhttp://www.theoceancleanup.com

By conducting visual surveys the Ocean Cleanup will be able to estimate the amounts and types of objects floating in our oceans. This knowledge is crucial to develop technologies to clean it up. Your help is greatly appreciated!

Julia Reisser (Ocean Research)
Harrie Pieters (App Developer, UI and UX)
Bart Sturm (UX, Server and Testing)
Eva Seignette (Testing) 
Daniel Baker (Icons)
